pulls.title: Define rules for a single group in robots.txt
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
This reworks the robots.txt syntax as discussed on the list.

This looks longer than what was there previously, but this is because it works.  The previous one was likely unworkable.

This assumes content in the vocabulary draft that is added by #26 and #35, which define the format and how multiple items can be combined, respectively.  If the sections in those move around or we don't decide to pursue that approach, then we'll need to adjust this accordingly.

pulls.title: Add attachment draft links to the README
pulls.author: martinthomson

pulls.title: Update the vocab reference in preparation for submission
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body: I need this to use automatically-generated tags or the submissions will refer to the wrong (older) versions.

pulls.title: Update acknowledgments
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
The IETF policy is that people participate as individuals, which means that we do not generally list affiliation when it comes to acknowledgments.  There's a carve-out for authorship and a few other things, but this is how we generally operate.

The formatting ensures that people can use their actual name.  Not a problem for these all-ASCII names, but it might end up being a problem later.

I've also sorted the list (by first name, which is my preferred approach once we have to deal with people who put family names first and all that).

There are probably a few other people that we might add here, though I want to be clear about the level of contribution before doing that. Both Brad and Felix have been very helpful on-list lately.

pulls.title: A reframing of search
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
As discussed on the list recently.

This does not include Brad's suggestion of "for the exclusive purpose of".  That is an important clarification, but I think we need to address that separately.  That is, we need to recognize that what we conceive of as "search" applications are more complicated than a simple index that is used to locate stuff.  We need commentary that explains that a single application can embody multiple usage categories and that use of assets for each of those aspects can have separate rules.  This isn't necessarily how those applications are built today[^1], but that's not necessarily a constraint on what we do.

[^1]: I am reminded of the concept of a "data lake", which has no distinction about where data has come from, the purpose for which it was obtained, or anything along those lines, making compliance with data protection regulation impossible.  The analogy here is with respect to use of assets for multiple purposes, without distinction.  For data lakes, the introduction of things like GDPR helped application developers build discipline about how they obtain and label personal information; perhaps this requires a similar shift, albeit one that affects a smaller set of people.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Made obsolete by #58.

pulls.title: Rework abbreviations
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body: This makes them consistent with how we've been talking about them.

pulls.title: Rewote the language on embedded preferences and removed FTP
pulls.author: lrosenthol
pulls.body:
I rewrote the section on embedded preferences to make it clear that the issue is the content type and not the actual payload, and gave XMP as an example.

Also removed the reference to FTP, since we're pretty sure it won't work.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: RFC 9309 does mention FTP, but that's probably not worth belaboring.
We'll need a citation for XMP, even if it is just normative.  Do you have a link?
Separately, it occurs that maybe we want to acknowledge the potential for the encoding to differ between formats.
The official ISO version is at https://www.iso.org/standard/75163.html.  The Adobe version is at https://github.com/adobe/XMP-Toolkit-SDK/blob/main/docs/XMPSpecificationPart1.pdf

But it doesn't.  Having added support for C2PA to dozens of different formats (https://c2pa.org/specifications/specifications/2.2/specs/C2PA_Specification.html#_supported_formats), I can speak authoritatively that no such changes are required.

pulls.title: Update search category
pulls.author: paul2keller
pulls.body: Narrowed down the scope of the proposed search category, which better reflects the status of the discussion on the mailing list

pulls.title: Tighten TDM language
pulls.author: paul2keller
pulls.body: Minor adjustments to the definition of TDM using more generic language, which further differentiates it from the definition provided in the EU Directive. (I have left the name of the category unchanged as changing that breaks lots of internal references, but I assume we will likely change the name as well)
